metadata.name: Pedagogical Approaches
metadata.description: Core pedagogical philosophies and teaching methodologies. Covers constructivism, direct instruction, inquiry-based learning, experiential learning, collaborative learning, differentiated instruction, project-based learning, problem-based learning, flipped classroom, and mastery learning.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Philosophical and methodological frameworks for teaching and facilitating learning

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Pedagogical approaches vary in how much autonomy they grant learners

positive_examples: Our school follows a constructivist approach where students build their own understanding.
The Montessori method emphasizes self-directed activity and hands-on learning.
We've adopted project-based learning as our primary pedagogical framework.
The Socratic method uses questioning to stimulate critical thinking.
negative_examples: The test scores improved this semester.
Students completed their homework on time.
The classroom had thirty desks arranged in rows.
training_hints.disambiguation: Overarching teaching philosophy, not specific techniques or outcomes

candidates.definition: Learning theory where learners actively construct knowledge through experience and reflection rather than passive reception

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Constructivism emphasizes learner agency in knowledge building

positive_examples: Students develop their own understanding by connecting new information to prior knowledge.
The lesson lets learners discover principles through hands-on experimentation.
Rather than memorizing facts, students build mental models through active exploration.
Knowledge is constructed, not transmitted - learners make meaning from experience.
negative_examples: The teacher lectured while students took notes.
Students memorized the multiplication tables through drill.
The instructor explained the correct answer step by step.
training_hints.disambiguation: Active knowledge construction, not passive reception

candidates.definition: Structured, teacher-led approach with explicit teaching of concepts through clear explanations and guided practice

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Neutral teaching method without autonomy implications

positive_examples: I will demonstrate the procedure step by step, then you practice while I observe.
The teacher explicitly modeled the problem-solving strategy before students tried it.
First I explain, then we do it together, then you try independently.
Clear, systematic instruction with immediate corrective feedback.
negative_examples: Students explored the materials freely without guidance.
The class discussed what they thought might happen before testing.
Learners discovered the principle through trial and error.
training_hints.disambiguation: Explicit teacher-led instruction, not discovery learning

candidates.definition: Learning through questioning, investigation, and discovery rather than direct transmission of information

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Inquiry-based learning centers learner questions and agency

positive_examples: Students formulated their own research questions and designed experiments to answer them.
What do you think would happen if we changed this variable?
The lesson started with a puzzling phenomenon that students investigated.
Rather than giving answers, the teacher asked probing questions to guide discovery.
negative_examples: Open your textbooks to page 42 and read the explanation.
Here's the formula - now apply it to these problems.
The correct answer is B because of the following reasons.

candidates.definition: Learning through direct experience, reflection, conceptualization, and active experimentation

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Learning modality without direct autonomy implications

positive_examples: After the field trip, students reflected on what they observed and formed new hypotheses.
Learning by doing - the internship gave hands-on experience with real projects.
The simulation let students experience the consequences of their decisions firsthand.
We process concrete experiences through reflective observation and abstract conceptualization.
negative_examples: Read chapter 5 and answer the questions at the end.
The lecture covered the theoretical foundations.
Students studied the case from the textbook.
training_hints.disambiguation: Learning from direct experience, not from texts or lectures

candidates.definition: Learning through group interaction, peer discussion, and collective knowledge construction

positive_examples: Students worked in small groups to solve the problem together.
The jigsaw activity had each team member become an expert to teach others.
Peer discussion helped students articulate and refine their understanding.
Learning happens through dialogue and negotiation of meaning with others.
negative_examples: Each student worked independently at their desk.
The test was taken individually with no communication allowed.
The teacher called on students one at a time to answer.

candidates.definition: Adapting teaching methods, content, and assessment to meet diverse learner needs and abilities

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Respects individual learner needs and paths

positive_examples: Students chose from three different reading levels on the same topic.
The teacher provided scaffolded versions of the assignment for different skill levels.
Advanced learners received extension activities while others got additional support.
Multiple pathways to the same learning goal accommodate different learning styles.
negative_examples: Everyone completed the same worksheet at the same pace.
All students took the identical test regardless of preparation.
The lecture proceeded at a fixed rate for the whole class.

candidates.definition: Learning through extended projects that involve investigation and response to complex questions or challenges

positive_examples: Students spent six weeks designing and building a sustainable garden.
The driving question guided their research: How can we reduce food waste in our cafeteria?
They presented their findings to a panel of community members.
The project integrated math, science, and communication skills.
negative_examples: Complete the worksheet by Friday.
Read the chapter and answer the questions.
The unit test covers chapters 3-5.
training_hints.disambiguation: Extended project work, not short assignments

candidates.definition: Learning through working on open-ended, real-world problems that drive the acquisition of knowledge

positive_examples: Students were presented with a patient case and had to diagnose the condition.
The ill-structured problem had no single right answer.
They had to figure out what they needed to learn to solve the problem.
Real-world problems drive the need for new knowledge.
negative_examples: Solve problems 1-20 at the end of the chapter.
The teacher explained the concept, then gave practice problems.
Follow this step-by-step procedure.
training_hints.disambiguation: Open-ended problem drives learning, not exercises after instruction

candidates.definition: Inverting traditional instruction by delivering content outside class and using class time for active application

positive_examples: Students watch the lecture video at home and do problem-solving in class.
Class time is reserved for discussion, application, and getting help.
The homework is watching the lesson; classwork is applying it.
Freed from lecturing, the teacher can work one-on-one with struggling students.
negative_examples: The teacher lectures during class and assigns homework after.
Students read at home and take notes in class.
Traditional classroom with teacher talking and students listening.
training_hints.disambiguation: Content delivered outside class, application in class

candidates.definition: Approach requiring demonstrated competence at each level before advancing, with flexible pacing and remediation

positive_examples: Students must score 80% or higher before moving to the next unit.
Those who didn't master the concept received additional instruction and retested.
Time is the variable; mastery is the constant.
You advance when you demonstrate competence, not when the calendar says so.
negative_examples: Everyone moves on to chapter 5 next Monday regardless of scores.
You got a C, but we're moving on anyway.
The class progresses together at a fixed pace.
